FacilityName: Evans Fruit Company-Tieton Main/Lust Cold Storage

_prev_prog_3.Description: The Evans Fruit Company has a PSM and RMP, which covers machine room 1. The information for machine room 1 is given in this section. The system is monitored by a computer control system. This system is connected by auto dialer to the phone system so if there is an alarm condition, a refrigeration operator is notified, and they must respond to clear the alarm condition. The system has ammonia detection in all refrigerated areas of the facility, with automatic shutdown and pumpout if ammonia is detected. All pressure vessels have safety relief valves, and all compressors have high pressure safety cutouts. The computer control system will both unload compressors on high system pressure, or stop compressors to prevent a high pressure (ammonia release) condition. All employees who work at the facility are trained in the emergency action plan, and are instructed in what they should do if an ammonia release occurs.

Prevention Program Description:

The Evans Fruit Company has a PSM and RMP, which covers machine room 1, 2, and 3. The

information for machine room 1 is given in this section. The system is monitored by a

computer control system. This system is connected by auto dialer to the phone system so if

there is an alarm condition, a refrigeration operator is notified, and they must respond to

clear the alarm condition. The system has ammonia detection in all refrigerated areas of the

facility, with automatic shutdown and pumpout if ammonia is detected. All pressure vessels

have safety relief valves, and all compressors have high pressure safety cutouts. The

computer control system will both unload compressors on high system pressure, or stop

compressors to prevent a high pressure (ammonia release) condition. All employees who

work at the facility are trained in the emergency action plan, and are instructed in what they

should do if an ammonia release occurs.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Program Approach

Evans Fruit Company, Inc. has implemented the OSHA PSM and the EPA RMP, which includes written descriptions of all the elements for these programs requirements.  To strive for a coordinated and affective program particular persons have been identified and assigned responsibility for carrying out the requirements of each element of these programs.  There is however a single person identified who has overall responsibility for the PSM and RMP.  Most all of the program elements are reviewed annually to keep the program current with personnell training and system requirements.  The entire program is scheduled to be reviewed at least every 3 years in a complete documentation compliance audit review.  Any audit recommendations to improve any program elements are addressed in a timely manner.  A process hazard analysis has been done for the entire system, and the hazard analysis will be repeated at least every 5 years, or more often if required by changes to the system)s).  A follow-up report is also generated and all recommendations from the hazard analysis are addressed to further improve the safety and integrity of the ammonia refrigeration system.  It is intended that the PSM/RMP for the Tieton Main-Warehouse Facility be actively used, reviewed, and improved as needed to assure the safety of the employees, the public, and the environment.  It is expected that by following the work practices that are implemented at the facility only incidental releases of ammonia will occur due to routine maintenance procedures, or normal equipment wear and tear.



Facility

This facility is used for the storage and packaging of fruit products, primarily apples.  The facility has a combination of controlled atomosphere rooms and non-controlled atmosphere rooms.  The facility is in operation year round from the time freshly picked fruit is brought into the rooms, until the next harvest season begins.  The refrigeration system uses ammonia, which is not only efficient b

ut also easily detectable at very low concentrations.  The entire refrigeration system is controlled by a computer, which also provides alarming and auto-dial notification to the refrigeration technition if some control parameter is out of acceptable limits.



Release Considerations

Following program guidlines, a Worse Case release of ammonia was analyzed.  Also several alternative (much more likely to occur) releases were considered.  Both the worse and alternative cases were documented in a report.  The alternative releases were in most cases releases that were of potential concern as determined in the Process Hazard Analysis of the system and facility.  The information generated from the consideration of the worse and alternative releases is used in developing the emergency action plan for the facility, and for coordination with local emergency responders.



Five year release history.  No releases.

This system has not had any reportable releases of ammonia in the last five year period.  If any actual release occured or even a near miss, an incident investigation would be done to determine the cause, and to find means or methods to reduce the possibility of a similar future occurence.



Emergemcy Action Plan

This facility has a written Emergency Action Plan that will be followed in the event of any type of emergency including the release of ammonia.  All responses by Evans Fruit employees and the refrigeration technicians will be defensive actions to control and contain an ammonia release until outside responders arrive to take offensive actions as appropriate for a release.  Evans Fruit does evacuation drills at least annually with all employees at the facility to assure safe and appropriate actions are taken.



Planned Safety Improvement

This facility holds monthly safety meetings with all Management Staff and Supervisors where all aspects of safety are discussed in regards to improving and maintaining a safe work environment.  Minutes of these meetings

are kept and used to monitor progress toward safety and operational improvements of any items discussed and agreed upon.  Systems and procedures are reviewed and uupdated; in many cases annually to assure that all operations are being done in a safe and effective manner, and operatin procedure will continue to be developed and improved.
